oai_dc:dc.dc:title: General Hooker at Lookout Valley Headquarters with generals and staff

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Military headquarters; Log cabins; Military officers; Military uniforms
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Hooker, Joseph, 1814-1879
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Union General Joseph Hooker with generals and staff. Hooker appears as the central figure (Number 3); Number 2 is General Daniel Butterfield; Number 1 is General John W. Geary; and Number 4 is General William G. Le Duc. A Capt. Hall and Capt. Kibler are also in the photo. All are pictured in front of log cabins with canvas roofs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: [Linn, J. B.]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: After the defeat of the U.S. Army at the Battle of Chickamauga, President Lincoln sent General Hooker with forces to help break the Confederate siege of Chattanooga. General Grant and General George Thomas joined to help establish a new supply line. Hooker took Lookout Valley as Thomas prepared to break out of Chattanooga. Hooker then took Lookout Mountain and continued to pursue retreating Confederates. He remained headquartered in Lookout Valley until the Atlanta Campaign in May 1864.
